I live in the Borough of Barnsley with my Fiancee and our mad cocker spaniel Wesley. I have lived here for over ten years
I live in the Borough of Barnsley with my Fiancee and our mad cocker spaniel Wesley. I have lived here for over ten years.
My political CV includes being a member of the Conservative Party for as long as I can remember. I have held various roles, including Deputy Chairman of two Associations, Chairman of one Conservative Association and Chairman of South Yorkshire Conservatives.
I stood to be elected 3 years ago in Barnsley (Hoyland Milton), missing out by just over 100 votes. The following year (after a determined and prolonged campaign)I was elected as a Conservative Councillor in Barnsley Rockingham Ward (some feat).
Becoming rapidly disillusioned with Conservative policies, along with PartyGate, lockdowns, leadership changes, and much more, I contacted Reform UK and liked what I saw and heard. Almost 2 years ago I defected to Reform UK and haven’t looked back.
In my minimal spare time, I enjoy gardening, cooking, traveling, and reading (mainly political biographies and autobiographies).
I aim to balance my reading, and one of the most compelling books that I have read in recent years was a biography of Jeremy Corbyn. Whilst I tend to agree with most of the UK that his politics are bonkers, his belief, consistency and self determination I found admirable.
The political will and determination of Mrs Thatcher has shaped so many politicians views from many parties, most famously perhaps Tony Blair. Her autobiographies were insightful, especially her views and stance on Europe as we now look back over the last 25 years or so.
On a local level, I feel that the miners were politicised and that the area is still recovering. Im delighted to say that Reform UK supports in full the findings of the BEIS report into miners pensions.
Since being elected in 2022 I feel that I have helped many residents to the best of my abilities. Small wins include
- Major Road Resurfacing
- Resident fencing where EVRi has been invasive
- Countless neighbourly dispute interventions and amicable solutions
- Setting up the initial EVRi liaison meetings with Councillors and residents
- Dangerous trees felled in many areas
- Initiating emergency bin collections
- Opposing further green belt development
- Working closely with SYP across many issues
- Opposing and now observing Primrose Way change of use planning.
- Hoyland Market Place (Say no more)
- Warehouse and factory noise management
- Achieving additional waste bins for Rockingham
- Countless pot-hole and fly-tipping reports and rectifications
- Signposted many residents to professional services for help and advice.

SYP Observer Shifts
13 May 2024How Will Labour Handle Woke?
Firstly, a definition of “woke’, this new buzzword, may be appropriate.
The Cambridge Dictionary, somewhat vaguely describes ‘Woke’ as the following: ‘aware, especially of social problems such as racism and inequality’.
However, many people have a different view. Many people see a minority of leftie labour activists who are simply stirring up the woke agenda for a variety of personal reasons.
Traditionally, the Labour Party consisted of mainly working-class people, in agreement with most things societal. Family, a strong work ethic, community, and care of these beliefs that transcended personal wealth or materialism.
With the shift to London-centric Labour members and activists since Blair came to power, many of them privileged graduates and ‘rich kids’, some in the Labour Party looked for a new voice of dissent, and ‘wokeism’ was born. Social media gave them an easy voice, and collectively, new ‘issues’ became apparent that historically were never considered.
Same-sex marriage was made legal by David Cameron, with minimal debate or opposition. Fine, even though our Christian-based democratic country had lived for centuries accepting the statute of marriage, both religiously and legally.
One issue that constantly hits the headlines (even though fuelled by a tiny percentage of the UK population) is gender identity. In most circles where this may be discussed, some very strong opinions are voiced. Labour and Conservatives have simply skirted around the penis / vagina debate for fear of upsetting the woke minority.
However, many women, who have strived for equal rights in their workplaces for many years are now seeing fully mature men, identifying as women, using female changing rooms and toilets. This has to be a backwards step for women and women’s rights.
A huge issue with ‘wokeism’ is the inability to respond or debate someone’s views without them resorting to ‘offence’ or even hate crime allegations. Surely everyone has a right to speak out in debate without being closed down with these cheap jibes. Even the Police have jumped on board with this, investigating social media posts that may offend some people.
The Racial and Religious Hatred Act 2006 and the Equality Act 2010 have placed huge power in the hands of the police and courts. Much of the legislation is valid, but elements such as ‘making it a criminal offence to use words which, in certain circumstances may be deemed ‘insulting’ or ‘abusive’, or to send a communication that may be deemed ‘grossly offensive’ have the potential to be misapplied.
In 2018 South Yorkshire Police tweeted ‘In addition to reporting hate crime, please report non-crime hate incidents, which can include things like offensive or insulting comments, online, in person or in writing. Hate will not be tolerated in South Yorkshire”
Is it the job of the police to decide what offends some people and not others? Policing the streets is one thing. It is a dangerous step to allow ‘policing of the mind’.
Freedom of speech is a fundamental part of our democracy and heritage. Indeed, if people hadn’t spoken out over centuries, our country would be much poorer. Debate is almost impossible now, and this is dangerous territory and a step toward Totalitarianism when a minority controls the voice of most of the population.
So it will be interesting to see how Labour handles ‘woke’. If they dare even acknowledge its’ very existence.

On a more serious note though, there is much speculaton that these ‘pioneering’ vehicles, fuelled (pardon the pun) by political will over retail desire in many cases, will be archaic and worthless in the next 10 years, as technology and hydrogen take over.
Many similarities I feel with the original mobile phones. Technology rampaged and rendered them worthless. But a huge difference here is the outlay of a few hundred pounds for early phones to the many thousands of pounds ‘invested’ in EV’s.
All this, just as the internal combustion engine reaches close to perfection.
Charging
EV aficionados will tell us how the charging network is fit for purpose, and charging times are acceptable. More honest EV drivers tell me that if they can find a charger that works, you can bet your life someone else has just plugged in for 20 mins in front of them, doubling the time spent buying unwanted coffee and lounging around counting down the minutes left until the next meeting 20KWH away.
In my view, not only buyers but also manufacturers should be given the choice of which vehicle to manufacture and people to buy. The UK’s insignificant net contribution to Co2 emissions renders EVs pretty much irrelevant in the Net Zero crusade that the BRIC economies flaunt in our faces.
China
The cheap influx of Chinese vehicles has the motor manufacturing industry quaking across the globe. Subsidised factories and tax breaks ensure that their cheaper cars are achieving a foothold in many Western markets, the UK included.
Biden’s response – to simply add a 100% tariff, doubling the price of imported Chinese cars. And that won’t receive a robust response Joe?
Government Responsibility
Just like encouraging everyone to buy diesel cars not so many years ago, then U-turning, phasing our internal combustion engines (then extending the period), I see this as an ill-conceived and politically driven strategy that takes away freedom of choice for the consumer and manufacturers, where many thousands of jobs are at risk.
Heat pumps, additional mathematics, and age restrictions on buying cigarettes, are we experiencing 1984, albeit 40 years late.

Its not just happening in Barnsley, it is happening across the UK. Over-development of areas with housing and industry but seemingly without the consideration of local infrastructure and highways.
I drive around new housing estates and see the brand new waste disposal sewer pipes being put in place, knowing that they are all feeding into existing sewers, some of which are hundreds of years old and certainly not designed to carry the expected capacity.
The housing crisis is well known. However, many say that simply building more houses is not the answer? That sounds fairly contradictory, supply and demand. But this may well be the crux of the issue.
Our net immigration in this country is beyond critical. The Cameron Government pledged to achieve net-migration around 10,000, but here we are around 500,000 p/a. So do we simply build more houses for immigrants, legal or illegal?
Lets be very clear about this, house builders certainly don’t want to flood the market with new, affordable housing. What’s that going to do for their profits? And who can blame them, they are in business to make money.
House prices are too high, something immediately obvious when comparing prices with Europe. And the Government (along with Labour before) have not addressed basic planning law that allows developers to secure land for building then gradually drip-feed properties and housing estates into the market to achieve maximum yield per acre.
Add into the mix the high number of foreign investors buying property in the UK for rental, and the housing crisis looks set to continue.
Just like the NHS, defence, the economy, policing, the court system and most other public services here, radical reform is needed, as the last 20 years have shown no progress, only regression.

It’s no secret that the EVRi deal was not an overnight decision by EVRi or BMBC.
Timing is everything, and in many residents views, the Covid lockdowns presented an opportunity to announce the plans for the largest parcel distribution hub in Europe on Hoylands once greenspace’.
The ink had hardly dried on the planning department’s approval (whilst residents were locked down, shielding) as the first steel structures sprouted up in proud defiance of residents’ views and vehement opposition.
I received a fair amount of ‘flak’ for opposing the EVRI development (and look what else has sprung up since), but I have also spoken to literally countless residents whose lives (let alone property values) have been affected forever.
Olympus Way may have relieved traffic on Sheffield Road, at the considerable cost of light pollution, increased HGV traffic around the entire area, the destruction of wildlife habitats and the once beautiful views gone forever.
I argued against the economic ‘benefits’ that warehousing brings to communities, and have been proved to be right. Low-paid labour is shipped in and out at each shift, contributing next to nothing to our town’s economy other than a bottle of pop at the CO-OP.
Low-paid staff are often receiving top-up benefits, so there is no wealth creation. They can not aspire to buy a house here, raise a family, or dare I say, contribute to the community.
Yet ”we’ continue to attract rate-paying sheds to the once lovely area, with only one winner – the business owners.

My Politics:
I have had a lifelong interest in politics. Until a couple of years ago I was a member of the Conservative Party (after a brief dalliance with The Brexit Party.
Having seen the Conservatives self destruction over the last decade, I switched to Reform UK.
I believe in mildly right-of-centre politics, much as was the state of the UK in the 1980’s and early 1990’s Conservatives.
Pretty much most of Reform UK’s Contract with the People I agree. with. Controlled Immigration, an immediate halt to illegal immigration, fixing the NHS (fully costed solution), increased defence spending, care for our valued veterans and much more, please take a read.
I believe in minimal state intervention (the opposite of what is happening right now), and in a welfare state that is a safety net for those that genuinely need it.
I believe that we have been influenced too strongly by a liberal woke agenda that criticises free speech.
“We have a new national religion – liberal wokedom – and anyone who blasphemes against it can expect to be vilified by its high priests and followers”.
Those who hold positions of prominence or influence had better be careful, for they risk seeing their reputations or livelihoods destroyed if they dare express dissent.
Real debate is very difficult now, as one party may claim to have been offended’ at what has been said. Healthy debate generates balanced outcomes, but not when parties or individuals become obsessed with labels and agendas that stifle even considered commentary.
Our democracy is built on the virtues of freedom of speech, I believe that this should be fought for in order to return to common sense debate.

Privacy Policy
==============
Last updated: May 14, 2024
This Privacy Policy describes Our policies and procedures on the collection,
use and disclosure of Your information when You use the Service and tells You
about Your privacy rights and how the law protects You.
We use Your Personal data to provide and improve the Service. By using the
Service, You agree to the collection and use of information in accordance with
this Privacy Policy.
Interpretation and Definitions
——————————
Interpretation
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The words of which the initial letter is capitalized have meanings defined
under the following conditions. The following definitions shall have the same
meaning regardless of whether they appear in singular or in plural.
Definitions
~~~~~~~~~~~
For the purposes of this Privacy Policy:
* Account means a unique account created for You to access our Service or
parts of our Service.
* Affiliate means an entity that controls, is controlled by or is under
common control with a party, where “control” means ownership of 50% or
more of the shares, equity interest or other securities entitled to vote
for election of directors or other managing authority.
* Company (referred to as either “the Company”, “We”, “Us” or “Our” in this
Agreement) refers to David White Reform UK.
* Cookies are small files that are placed on Your computer, mobile device or
any other device by a website, containing the details of Your browsing
history on that website among its many uses.
* Country refers to: United Kingdom
* Device means any device that can access the Service such as a computer, a cellphone or a digital tablet.
* Personal Data is any information that relates to an identified or
identifiable individual.
* Service refers to the Website.
* Service Provider means any natural or legal person who processes the data
on behalf of the Company. It refers to third-party companies or
individuals employed by the Company to facilitate the Service, to provide
the Service on behalf of the Company, to perform services related to the
Service or to assist the Company in analyzing how the Service is used.
* Usage Data refers to data collected automatically, either generated by the
use of the Service or from the Service infrastructure itself (for example,
the duration of a page visit).
* Website refers to David White Reform UK, accessible from
[davidwhitereform.uk](davidwhitereform.uk)
* You means the individual accessing or using the Service, or the company,
or other legal entity on behalf of which such individual is accessing or
using the Service, as applicable.
Collecting and Using Your Personal Data
—————————————
Types of Data Collected
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Personal Data
*************
While using Our Service, We may ask You to provide Us with certain personally
identifiable information that can be used to contact or identify You.
Personally identifiable information may include, but is not limited to:
* Email address
* First name and last name
* Usage Data
Usage Data
**********
Usage Data is collected automatically when using the Service.
Usage Data may include information such as Your Device’s Internet Protocol
address (e.g. IP address), browser type, browser version, the pages of our
Service that You visit, the time and date of Your visit, the time spent on
those pages, unique device identifiers and other diagnostic data.
When You access the Service by or through a mobile device, We may collect
certain information automatically, including, but not limited to, the type of
mobile device You use, Your mobile device unique ID, the IP address of Your
mobile device, Your mobile operating system, the type of mobile Internet
browser You use, unique device identifiers and other diagnostic data.
We may also collect information that Your browser sends whenever You visit our
Service or when You access the Service by or through a mobile device.
Tracking Technologies and Cookies
*********************************
We use Cookies and similar tracking technologies to track the activity on Our
Service and store certain information. Tracking technologies used are beacons,
tags, and scripts to collect and track information and to improve and analyze
Our Service. The technologies We use may include:
* Cookies or Browser Cookies. A cookie is a small file placed on Your
Device. You can instruct Your browser to refuse all Cookies or to indicate
when a Cookie is being sent. However, if You do not accept Cookies, You
may not be able to use some parts of our Service. Unless you have adjusted
Your browser setting so that it will refuse Cookies, our Service may use
Cookies.
* Web Beacons. Certain sections of our Service and our emails may contain
small electronic files known as web beacons (also referred to as clear
gifs, pixel tags, and single-pixel gifs) that permit the Company, for
example, to count users who have visited those pages or opened an email
and for other related website statistics (for example, recording the
popularity of a certain section and verifying system and server
integrity).
Cookies can be “Persistent” or “Session” Cookies. Persistent Cookies remain on
Your personal computer or mobile device when You go offline, while Session
Cookies are deleted as soon as You close Your web browser. You can learn more
about cookies on [TermsFeed
website](https://www.termsfeed.com/blog/cookies/#What_Are_Cookies) article.
We use both Session and Persistent Cookies for the purposes set out below:
* Necessary / Essential Cookies
Type: Session Cookies
Administered by: Us
Purpose: These Cookies are essential to provide You with services
available through the Website and to enable You to use some of its
features. They help to authenticate users and prevent fraudulent use of
user accounts. Without these Cookies, the services that You have asked for
cannot be provided, and We only use these Cookies to provide You with
those services.
* Cookies Policy / Notice Acceptance Cookies
Type: Persistent Cookies
Administered by: Us
Purpose: These Cookies identify if users have accepted the use of cookies
on the Website.
* Functionality Cookies
Type: Persistent Cookies
Administered by: Us
Purpose: These Cookies allow us to remember choices You make when You use
the Website, such as remembering your login details or language
preference. The purpose of these Cookies is to provide You with a more
personal experience and to avoid You having to re-enter your preferences
every time You use the Website.
For more information about the cookies we use and your choices regarding
cookies, please visit our Cookies Policy or the Cookies section of our Privacy
Policy.
Use of Your Personal Data
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The Company may use Personal Data for the following purposes:
* To provide and maintain our Service , including to monitor the usage of
our Service.
* To manage Your Account: to manage Your registration as a user of the
Service. The Personal Data You provide can give You access to different
functionalities of the Service that are available to You as a registered
user.
* For the performance of a contract: the development, compliance and
undertaking of the purchase contract for the products, items or services
You have purchased or of any other contract with Us through the Service.
* To contact You: To contact You by email, telephone calls, SMS, or other
equivalent forms of electronic communication, such as a mobile
application’s push notifications regarding updates or informative
communications related to the functionalities, products or contracted
services, including the security updates, when necessary or reasonable for

* To provide You with news, special offers and general information about
other goods, services and events which we offer that are similar to those
that you have already purchased or enquired about unless You have opted
not to receive such information.
* To manage Your requests: To attend and manage Your requests to Us.
* For business transfers: We may use Your information to evaluate or conduct
a merger, divestiture, restructuring, reorganization, dissolution, or
other sale or transfer of some or all of Our assets, whether as a going
concern or as part of bankruptcy, liquidation, or similar proceeding, in
which Personal Data held by Us about our Service users is among the assets
transferred.
* For other purposes : We may use Your information for other purposes, such
as data analysis, identifying usage trends, determining the effectiveness
of our promotional campaigns and to evaluate and improve our Service,
products, services, marketing and your experience.
We may share Your personal information in the following situations:
* With Service Providers: We may share Your personal information with
Service Providers to monitor and analyze the use of our Service, to
contact You.
* For business transfers: We may share or transfer Your personal information
in connection with, or during negotiations of, any merger, sale of Company
assets, financing, or acquisition of all or a portion of Our business to
another company.
* With Affiliates: We may share Your information with Our affiliates, in
which case we will require those affiliates to honor this Privacy Policy.
Affiliates include Our parent company and any other subsidiaries, joint
venture partners or other companies that We control or that are under
common control with Us.
* With business partners: We may share Your information with Our business
partners to offer You certain products, services or promotions.
* With other users: when You share personal information or otherwise
interact in the public areas with other users, such information may be
viewed by all users and may be publicly distributed outside.
* With Your consent : We may disclose Your personal information for any
other purpose with Your consent.
Retention of Your Personal Data
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The Company will retain Your Personal Data only for as long as is necessary
for the purposes set out in this Privacy Policy. We will retain and use Your
Personal Data to the extent necessary to comply with our legal obligations
(for example, if we are required to retain your data to comply with applicable

The Company will also retain Usage Data for internal analysis purposes. Usage
Data is generally retained for a shorter period of time, except when this data
is used to strengthen the security or to improve the functionality of Our
Service, or We are legally obligated to retain this data for longer time

Transfer of Your Personal Data
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Your information, including Personal Data, is processed at the Company’s
operating offices and in any other places where the parties involved in the
processing are located. It means that this information may be transferred to —
and maintained on — computers located outside of Your state, province, country
or other governmental jurisdiction where the data protection laws may differ
than those from Your jurisdiction.
Your consent to this Privacy Policy followed by Your submission of such
information represents Your agreement to that transfer.
The Company will take all steps reasonably necessary to ensure that Your data
is treated securely and in accordance with this Privacy Policy and no transfer
of Your Personal Data will take place to an organization or a country unless
there are adequate controls in place including the security of Your data and
other personal information.
Delete Your Personal Data
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
You have the right to delete or request that We assist in deleting the
Personal Data that We have collected about You.
Our Service may give You the ability to delete certain information about You
from within the Service.
You may update, amend, or delete Your information at any time by signing in to
Your Account, if you have one, and visiting the account settings section that
allows you to manage Your personal information. You may also contact Us to
request access to, correct, or delete any personal information that You have
provided to Us.
Please note, however, that We may need to retain certain information when we
have a legal obligation or lawful basis to do so.
Disclosure of Your Personal Data
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Business Transactions
*********************
If the Company is involved in a merger, acquisition or asset sale, Your
Personal Data may be transferred. We will provide notice before Your Personal
Data is transferred and becomes subject to a different Privacy Policy.
Law enforcement
***************
Under certain circumstances, the Company may be required to disclose Your
Personal Data if required to do so by law or in response to valid requests by
public authorities (e.g. a court or a government agency).
Other legal requirements
************************
The Company may disclose Your Personal Data in the good faith belief that such
action is necessary to:
* Comply with a legal obligation
* Protect and defend the rights or property of the Company
* Prevent or investigate possible wrongdoing in connection with the Service
* Protect the personal safety of Users of the Service or the public
* Protect against legal liability
Security of Your Personal Data
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The security of Your Personal Data is important to Us, but remember that no
method of transmission over the Internet, or method of electronic storage is
100% secure. While We strive to use commercially acceptable means to protect
Your Personal Data, We cannot guarantee its absolute security.
Children’s Privacy
——————
Our Service does not address anyone under the age of 13. We do not knowingly
collect personally identifiable information from anyone under the age of 13.
If You are a parent or guardian and You are aware that Your child has provided
Us with Personal Data, please contact Us. If We become aware that We have
collected Personal Data from anyone under the age of 13 without verification
of parental consent, We take steps to remove that information from Our

If We need to rely on consent as a legal basis for processing Your information
and Your country requires consent from a parent, We may require Your parent’s
consent before We collect and use that information.
Links to Other Websites
———————–
Our Service may contain links to other websites that are not operated by Us.
If You click on a third party link, You will be directed to that third party’s
site. We strongly advise You to review the Privacy Policy of every site You
visit.
We have no control over and assume no responsibility for the content, privacy

Changes to this Privacy Policy
——————————
We may update Our Privacy Policy from time to time. We will notify You of any
changes by posting the new Privacy Policy on this page.
We will let You know via email and/or a prominent notice on Our Service, prior
to the change becoming effective and update the “Last updated” date at the top

You are advised to review this Privacy Policy periodically for any changes.
Changes to this Privacy Policy are effective when they are posted on this
page.
Contact Us
———-
If you have any questions about this Privacy Policy, You can contact us:
* By email: info@davidwhitereform.uk

It is most kids’ dream (or used to be anyway) to spend a couple of hours with the local police on a shift in a police car, so when I approached SYP Hoyland Sgt. Jenkins about the possibility, he welcomed it.
SYP appreciated the exposure that my time with them generated, enough to be asked back late last year.
What did I learn? The ‘insider’ knowledge is incredible. Recognising people that may require some ‘attention’, cruising past properties that are known areas for crime, but also knowing the people that need help. Countless times we stopped to ask about the welfare of people in the street.
Its not all about chasing motorists with our blue lights & sirens, although I did have a taste of that, which was both nervy and enthralling. The result – needless to say I can’t mention it!
I also experienced an ‘incident’ that was most serious, involving imminent threats to life. I recognised the severity of the situation when I was told simply “David, maybe stay in the car for this one”. I did. And I’m pleased to report that it was a hoax call.
In summary, both nights were relatively ‘quiet’ which wasn’t a bad thing for me, but I did see plenty of ‘action’.
Ill stress again if I may, the local knowledge and awareness demonstrated by the officers was incredible. As was their commitment.

David White – Reform UK Barnsley South Spokesperson.South Yorkshire Co-Ordinator

What happened to the miners pension fund?
In 1994, a privatisation agreement was signed meaning the government would get half of any surplus cash from a miners’ pension scheme, in return for guaranteeing that pensions would increase. The government confirmed it had received £4.8bn from the scheme over the last 30 years.
The investments have generally been successful in generating excellent returns which has resulted in surpluses at some of the actuarial valuations. These surpluses have allowed the Trustees to award extra benefits to members, usually in the form of bonus pensions.
In April 2021 a cross-party committee of MPs said the government should stop taking money from the scheme and pay back some of what it had already received.
Ministers rejected those recommendations and data released to the BBC under Freedom of Information laws shows the government has received three annual payments of £142.4m since then.
While many schemes are overseen by the Pensions Regulator, the piece of law that led to this agreement means the government has sole responsibility.
Labour’s shadow energy security and net zero secretary Ed Miliband told the BBC there has been “deep unfairness and injustice” in the Conservative Party’s approach to the arrangement.
He said a Labour government would carry out a “comprehensive revision of the arrangements to make sure that miners get the fair share of the money to which they are entitled”.
Interestingly, this was never addresses at he time that Labour were in Government.
Reform UK supports the recommendations in the BEIS Miners Pension Report in full.

As well as being an active local Reform UK Cllr in Barnsley, having sat on the licensing, Standards, and Planning boards, I also hold a few roles within Reform UK.
I am the county Organiser, responsible for looking after Barnsley, Rotherham, Sheffield, and Doncaster candidates and activists.
I am also one of several Party members that interview potential Parliamentary candidates nationally.
I am also the first point of contact for anyone considering defecting from other political parties.
Campaigning
Campaigning with just a few of our hugely motivated activists across Barnsley South.
In all my time in politics, I have never before met such a determined group of people, who ‘get of their backsides’ for the first time to help bring much-needed change to the UK.
Humbling to see the support given by these passionate and caring people from all walks of life. Respect to you all.

Are you thinking of defecting to Reform UK?
It will come as no surprise that Reform UK talks to people in our position on a regular basis. From Parish Councillors, local Ward Councillors, Mayors, and Council Leaders, many across the country are feeling politically homeless and are liking what Reform UK is saying.
